webTitle: The fall in inflation will take living standards off the political agenda

fields.standfirst: As the gap between pay and the cost of living narrows, politicians will be less able to campaign on the 'squeezed middle'
fields.body:
Inflation is down to 1.7%, the lowest for more than four years. Some of the changes behind that fall will have been more obvious, such as the drop in petrol prices last month. Others were more subtle: clothing prices were up but by less than this time last year. But the good news for workers is that easing price pressures will become increasingly noticeable in their pockets in coming months as pay growth finally catches up with inflation, and hopefully overtakes it.

By one very loose measure, the gap has already closed. Average annual pay growth for January was 1.7%, according to data last week, although statisticians prefer us to use the less volatile three-month measure, which came in at 1.4%. Surveys suggest businesses will finally start passing on some of their recovering fortunes to workers so pay growth is expected to carry on rising.

This is welcome for people who have struggled with falling real wages for years, but not so helpful to politicians seeking to campaign on a cost of living crisis. Pay growth is up, inflation is down and the squeeze on living standards is dropping off the agenda.

webTitle: Kingfisher's retreat in China looks honourable | Nils Pratley

fields.standfirst: B&Q owner's losses in China were reduced to £6m last year – good enough to justify seeking a long-term partner
fields.body:
China defeats yet another British retailer. This time it is Kingfisher that is following Tesco's example and seeking a local joint venture partner for its B&Q chain. The explanation is similar too: tough local competitors; problems in finding management; a different consumer culture, in this case an expectation that the retailer doesn't just sell the paint but also supplies the decorator.

Sir Ian Cheshire, Kingfisher chief executive, can at least claim the Chinese retreat is honourable. Five years ago, when he was fresh in the job, losses in China were running at £50m or so. A third of the stores have been closed since then and losses last year were reduced to £6m.

That is deemed sufficiently encouraging to justify seeking a partner for the long term, rather than exiting China altogether. That judgment looks reasonable. Mind you, it would also have been reasonable in 1999, when Kingfisher first took B&Q to China. In those days, China was seen as a land of easy profits for slick western retailers; they all know better now.

Semi-resolution of the Chinese headache was one of several items in Cheshire's spring-clean. The 21% stake in German group Hornbach has been sold for £195m. And, as expected, Kingfisher will start to hand back excess capital to shareholders. There may be even be an outbreak a Lord Wolfson-style common sense of how the spoils are distributed. Rather than one big splurge, Kingfisher has opted for a "multi-year programme," starting with £200m this financial year. A view on whether a buy-back or special dividend makes more economic sense will be made at the time – very sensible too.

It was all enough to push the share price up 6% to 431p, at which level Kingfisher is valued at 18 times last year's earnings. For all the shareholder-friendly actions, that's not cheap. A stronger UK housing market will help, but profits in France are still treading water.

webTitle: No one formula for encouraging invention | @guardianletters

fields.body:
Larry Elliott asks if the innovations made by Formula One manufacturers cannot be used in the fight against climate change (When nudge comes to shove, 24 March). I agree. We sit on 400 years' worth of coal, we're surrounded by sea and wind. Surely the country that gave the world television, the jet engine, antibiotics and the world wide web, among other innovations, can lead the way to develop clean coal technology and use wind, tidal and solar power to give the UK both energy supply and security?

If Ed Miliband wants to set a bold radical manifesto, what could be bolder than to set Britain on a course of clean energy self-sufficiency? We own the banks to provide cheap long-term finance, so use the best brains and universities combined with our engineering genius to lead the green energy revolution providing skilled, well-paid jobs, factories and apprenticeships and leading to prosperity for our country.
Alan Quinn
Manchester

• While in some respects agreeing with Larry Elliott on behavioural economics, I take issue with his assertion that governments need to "be prepared to shove as well as nudge". He cites improvements to fuel and power efficiency made to Formula One cars as a result of stipulations made by its authorities. Extending this to car makers generally would impose costs on them in the event of recalls involving tens if not hundreds of thousands of models if they go wrong – nowhere near as draconian for the typical F1 team, which might have four or five models.

Furthermore, many breakthroughs, such as the discovery of penicillin and the technology behind microwave ovens, come about via fluke rather than intention. While there probably is a case for governments to fund R&D spending, setting rigid parameters and targets instead of allowing researchers to pursue their own proclivities might stymie this as a source of discoveries.
Paul Negrotti
Winchester, Hampshire

webTitle: George Osborne hopes for £4.2bn from sale of 7.5% stake in Lloyds Bank

fields.standfirst: Move suggests that the bailed-out bank will be back in private ownership before the general election next May
fields.body:
The government has moved a step closer to returning Lloyds Banking Group to the private sector as it kicked off the sale of a 7.5% stake in the bank, which is expected to raise up to £4.2bn.

It is the second time in six months that the taxpayers' stake has been reduced and underlines the increasing confidence in the once crisis-stricken bank. The move suggests that the bailed-out bank will be back in private ownership before the general election next May.

The stake was being placed with institutional investors, in line with advice from UK Financial Investments, which holds the stake on behalf of the government, that the latest sale be restricted to City investors. Chancellor George Osborne has outlined plans to allow small investors to buy up some of the shares, but City rules mean any sell-off to retail investors cannot take place for at least 90 days.

In February, when the bank reported a statutory profit of £415m but a loss of £802m after tax, the bank's chief executive António Horta-Osório declared that Lloyds was now "a normal bank" and he was awarded a bonus of £1.7m.

One well-placed source said UKFI opted for a placing of shares, rather than a wider offer, due to uncertainty about when Lloyds will restart dividend payments and volatility in the wider financial markets.

The share sale, which is likely to be completed on Wednesday, will see the 7.5% stake in the bank sold at a small discount to last night's closing price of 79.1p in order to encourage buyers. It will reduce the taxpayer's interest from 32.7% to about 25%.

Last September, the first tranche of Lloyds shares – a 6% stake – was sold at 75p, returning £3.2bn to Treasury coffers.

While the second round of share sales will be welcomed as a sign of growing confidence in the bank, the taxpayer's profit from the £20bn bail-out is very modest: the average price at which the government pumped cash into Lloyds in 2008, to prevent the bank collapsing, was 73.6p a share. The share price has climbed by more than 60% in the last year.

In his autumn statement last December Osborne declared his ambition that ordinary investors might soon be invited to acquire shares in future Lloyds sell-offs, saying UKFI was "developing the best mechanism" to allow the public to take part. "These preparations will allow those who rescued the bank to participate in its exit from government ownership," he said.

At the time of the annual resultsHorta-Osório said he had stabilised the bank and that Lloyds was ready to go back into private ownership: "The market, I think, is ready as well. I came to Lloyds three years ago to fix this bank and help taxpayers get their money back."

Horta-Osório added: "I am pleased that the government intends to sell a further stake in Lloyds Banking Group and allow taxpayers to get more of their money back. I believe this reflects the hard work undertaken over the last three years to make Lloyds a safe and profitable bank that is focused on helping Britain prosper."

A Treasury spokesman said: "The government set out its objectives for its shareholdings in the banks in the chancellor's annual Mansion House address last June – getting the best value for the taxpayer, maximising support for the economy and restoring private ownership – and, as set out in that address, the government will only conclude a sale if these objectives are met."

webTitle: Former Co-op bank boss recounts 'hellish' months after drugs revelation

fields.standfirst: Paul Flowers, dubbed the crystal methodist, says he spent 28 days before Christmas at a rehab clinic tackling his habit
fields.body:
Paul Flowers, the former Co-operative Bank chair and methodist minister exposed last year for allegedly taking drugs and booking male prostitutes, has spoken publicly for the first time about his addiction – revealing he spent a month in a rehab clinic, and describing the storm around his private and professional life in recent months as "hellish".

Flowers said he spent 28 days before Christmas at a well-known hospital tackling his drug habit, and he was still making weekly visits for treatment. He said that while still chairman of the bank, he had come under "considerable pressure" from ministers to conclude the Co-operative's much-publicised agreement to buy 600 branches from Lloyds.

The highly political deal, which would have helped recoup some of the millions in public money spent bailing out Lloyds during the credit crunch, was scrapped when the Co-operative's own financial troubles came to light.

"For me personally, there have been several months when it has been hellish, but during that process I've actually been very well supported by a raft of very good friends," Flowers told the BBC. "You certainly find out who your friends are, because a significant number of people in politics and in the Co-op and some in the church have been noticeable by their silence or their absence."

Flowers, who became known as the "crystal methodist" after the Mail on Sunday exposed his addiction, quit his £132,000-a-year job in June as the bank confessed to a £1.5bn capital shortfall. He has been asked to repay some cash to the mutual.

He was questioned about the collapse of the Lloyds deal by MPs on 6 November, when a shaky performance led to accusations from the Treasury select committee chairman, Andrew Tyrie, that Flowers did not know even "very basic" details of the bank's finances.

Three days later he was filmed in a car discussing cocaine and crystal meth that he wanted to get from a dealer in Leeds, counting off £300 in £20 notes and sending a friend to make the deal. Shortly after the revelations, Flowers sought help.

"I actually booked myself into a very well-known hospital for four weeks from the end of November until Christmas Eve and underwent what was called their addictions treatment programme for the 28 days that I was there," he said in an interview for BBC2's Newsnight programme.

"I found that both cathartic and traumatic but it actually helped me to look at not so much the superficial issues of the addictions themselves but the more deep-seated reasons why people resort to any sort of addiction, and for me that was life-changing. I am now much more secure in my own skin, much more self-aware than I was before."

A minister in Bradford since 1976, Flowers was suspended indefinitely by the church last year, and has since told parishioners he intends to retire.

He was arrested in November as part of a "drugs supply investigation" and is currently on bail. On the day after his appearance at the Commons, Flowers sent a text reading: "I was 'grilled' by the Treasury select committee yesterday and afterwards came to Manchester to get wasted with friends."

In the interview, Flowers suggested that any transgressions had occurred after he left the Co-operative board. He said: "Many of the things that have come into the public domain actually occurred after I had left office, and people assume that they had occurred before, but they are quite wrong."

Flowers has told of how he was pressured by ministers while still at the Co-operative to ensure that its deal to buy the Lloyds branches was approved. He claimed to have received calls "two or three times a week" from Mark Hoban, the Conservative who was City minister at the time.

"Clearly they wanted a deal which would help them in terms of public finances. They actually said that they were keen on Co-op becoming a much more significant player with more scale.

"We would have had about 7-8% of the market if this had gone through. And there was pressure certainly from Mark Hoban, but I believe and know that that originated much higher up with the chancellor himself."

In November, hedge funds and other private investors injected nearly £1bn into the Co-op bank to fill a black hole in its accounts. On Monday the bank revealed further losses relating to mis-selling of payment protection insurance and lapses in the provision of mortgages. It now plans to raise another £400m by issuing new shares.

webTitle: Rolls-Royce accused of sacking senior engineer for whistle-blowing

fields.standfirst: Company denies Hilmi Kurt-Elli's claim he was dismissed for raising potentially serious safety concerns over jet engines
fields.body:
Rolls-Royce has been accused of sacking a senior engineer after he blew the whistle on allegations of potentially serious problems with the company's jet engines.

Dr Hilmi Kurt-Elli, who was a senior design engineer on Rolls-Royce engines used on more than 30 different types of passenger jets, claimed at an employment tribunal on Tuesday that he was dismissed after raising safety concerns with the FTSE100 company's chief executive, John Rishton.

The company said it had thoroughly investigated Kurt-Elli's claims, which relate to alleged errors in a computer modelling system used in designing engines, and found "no evidence to substantiate product or safety integrity concerns".

Rolls-Royce said Kurt-Elli was not sacked for blowing the whistle, but for his unreasonable attitude and the total breakdown of his relationship with colleagues and senior executives.

Kath Durrant, Rolls-Royce's human resources director, told the tribunal in Nottingham she was horrified when she read Kurt-Elli's letter to Rishton outlining "a set of extraordinary allegations".

"I took your claims very seriously," she told Kurt-Elli. "A genuine whistleblower coming to us should expect to be taken very seriously, and that is what I did. We would have been on your side."

Durrant said investigators were called in to investigate Kurt-Elli's claims, first made in October 2011, and Rishton was personally briefed on their progress.

She said Kurt-Elli refused to accept the investigators' verdict that there was no evidence of any safety problem, and he went on to accuse Rishton and other senior executives of "corruption, potentially illegal acts and behaving unethically".

Durrant said Kurt-Elli alleged that "multiple layers of management were involved in a conspiracy to cover up information". Kurt-Elli, who was Rolls' vibration specialist until he was dismissed in February 2012, said it was his case "that the CEO and yourself [Durrant] conducted a sham investigation. It was designed specifically to not uncover the truth."

Durrant denied there were any safety concerns or a coverup. "Dr Kurt-Elli starts from the basis that everybody in the company is corrupt," Durrant said. "I started from wanting to understand what the hell was going on here."

Durrant said the company had no choice but to suspended, and later dismiss Kurt-Elli after he refused to accept the outcome of the investigation and continued to make serious allegations against "so many people".

"The claimant made personal attacks on everyone who would not agree with his position," she said. "I've never seen such language, such allegations used against colleagues. After such a long period of issuing the same allegations there was no relationship on which we could continue."

Kurt-Elli, who was representing himself at the tribunal, said: "People have lied, people have misled." He also alleged that the company did not follow a proper dismissal procedure. Rolls-Royce said the dismissal was carried out correctly.

Tribunal judge Richard Hutchinson said: "We have to decide whether you were dismissed because you made a protected disclosures [blew the whistle], or if it had all to do with your behaviour, not the disclosure.

"They say you made unfounded allegations about your work colleagues leading them to believe you could no longer work in the organisation. If we decide it was because of the protected disclosure, they are in trouble."

Kurt-Elli is seeking compensation of £450,000 from Rolls-Royce.

The tribunal continues.

The case comes as Rolls is subject to a criminal investigation into claims raised by separate whistleblowers that the company paid bribes in Indonesia and China.

fields.standfirst: But limited dividends mean the government may still be relying on institutional demand in the autumn

Roll up, roll up, for your shares in Lloyds Banking Group. Or rather, don't. This latest sale of a 7.5% stake, reducing the state's holding to 25%, is a strictly institutions-only affair. But the disposal is intended to clear the decks ahead of the government's long-promised offer to retail investors, which could happen in the autumn.

That's the one where the Treasury will have to swallow hard. Visions of a Royal Mail-style stampede of buyers seem fanciful. First, at Lloyds' current market value, 25% equals £14.5bn, which is a lot of stock to shift. Second, unlike the privatisation of the postal service, a giveaway at a huge discount is impossible because the market price is the public yardstick of value for money for taxpayers.

Third, Lloyds hasn't yet announced a dividend – and won't even apply to regulators to pay one until the autumn. Even when dividends do return, it will take time to reach the intended level of distribution of 50% of earnings. So Lloyds, at the moment of an autumn offer to retail investors, won't be a dividend geyser. That makes it a trickier pitch.

Indeed, it seems quite likely that the government will still be relying on institutional demand to underpin the final sale of Lloyds shares. The alternative course would be to wait until dividends are flowing properly. That, though, wouldn't fit the election timetable.

  • UK stock market rebounds from near-seven-week lows

5.38pm GMT

European markets buoyant

After days in the doldrums, stock markets have regained some of the recent lost ground. Continuing concerns about Ukraine seem to have been outweighed by talk of possible stimulus measures by Chinese authorities to boost the country's flagging economy, not to mention a host of positive corporate updates. The dovish comments from various members of the European Central Bank (see here onwards) has also helped sentiment. So the closing prices showed:

• The FTSE 100 finished 84.5 points or 1.3% higher at 6604.89

• Germany's Dax added 1.63% to 9338.4

• France's Cac closed 1.59% higher at 4344.12

• Italy's FTSE MIB ended 0.95% better at 20,823.16

• Spain's Ibex rose 0.78% to 9990.5

* Russia's Micex closed 2.04% higher at 1324.44

On Wall Street the Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently 120 points or 0.74%.

And on that note, it's time to close up for the evening. Thanks for all your comments, and we'll be back tomorrow.

Updated at 5.46pm GMT

5.14pm GMT

Over in Greece it’s been a different sort of day today as the country put on a military extravaganza to mark its Independence Day – with a show that officials said highlighted its exit from economic crisis. Helena Smith in Athens writes:

For the first time since the start of the debt crisis, authorities went all out putting much of the country's military arsenal on display as the nation marked the day that commemorates the start of Greece’s 1821 war of Independence against the Ottoman Empire.

Fighter jets and Apache helicopters flew overhead as tanks (many ironically procured from Germany) rolled down the streets. The extravanza had been put on hold by the former socialist prime minister George Papandreou when Greece was forced to turn to the EU, ECB and IMF for emergency rescue funds to avert bankruptcy in May 2010.

But addressing reporters after the parade, the defence minister Dimitirs Avramopoulos said the display had sent “a message of self-confidence” that highlighted the country’s economic recovery.

“Now that Greece has got through the worst, let us all work together for the better things that are on the horizon,” he said. “We have sent with this grand parade that so many thousands of Athenians and all of Greece has watched, a message of strength and peace … the Greece of crisis very shortly will not exist [because] the Greece of pride, self-confidence and strength is coming.”

The Greek president Karolos Papoulias went further likening the nation’s fight for freedom to the battle against foreign lenders much blamed for a four-year diet of austerity that has plunged the country into prolonged recession and record levels of poverty and unemployment.

“Today our people are waging a struggle to break the encirclement of creditors,” the 84-year-old head of state told reporters. “Our history guarantees that this fight will be victorious.”

With the plight of ordinary Greeks, hit by successive pay and pension cuts and tax increases worst than it has even been, the display of military might has been quick to spark controversy. Papandreou’s decision is believed to have brought down costs dramatically - from €3.1m to €350,000 for national day celebrations and those marking OXI day commemorating the beginning of Greece’s participation in World War II.

Security was such that with the exception of a smattering of invited officials, Greeks were unable to even get close to the parade. “It’s not just an outdated display of nationalism that has no place in Europe but an incredible waste of money at a time when economically things are better but nowhere near as successful as the government makes out,” the political commentator Paschos Mandravelis told the Guardian. “A lot of money has been spent needlessly on fuel and transport of all this equipment and to make things worse, most Greeks weren’t even able to see the parade. “

5.06pm GMT

Here is the official statement on the Lloyds share sale:

Intention to Dispose c. 7.5% Lloyds Banking Group

The news came after the market closed so has had no effect on the Lloyds shares price, which ended 0.61p higher at 79.11p.

Updated at 5.07pm GMT

4.41pm GMT

UK government to sell more Lloyds Banking Group shares

The government has just announced it plans to sell 5.35bn Lloyds Banking Group shares, or 7.5% of the group, in a placing to institutional investors.

This will cut the government's stake from 32.7% to around 25% and would raise just over £4bn at the current 79p share price.

4.23pm GMT

And after the comments from members of the European Central Bank's council on the prospect of further stimulus measures, comes president Mario Draghi himself, echoing the same theme.

Speaking in Paris, the ECB president said the central bank was ready to act if inflation slipped lower than it expected, that is, rising to 1% this year, 1.3% in 2015 and 1.5% in 2016, according to Reuters. He said:

If any downside risks to this scenario appear, we stand ready to take additional monetary policy measures that ensure our mandate is fulfilled.

We will do what is needed to maintain price stability.

Earlier various members of the ECB had hinted at the possible measures, including negative deposit rates and quantitative easing.

Draghi also said banks should take prompt action to fix any problems before the ECB unveiled its health checks on the sector, due in October. He said:

The cleaning up of bank balance sheets does not need to wait for the end of this assessment. The best outcome is one where banks are forward looking and take any corrective action before the end of the process.

And he concluded:

Winston Churchill said that “to achieve great things, two things are needed: a plan, and not quite enough time”. I hope that I have made clear today that we do have a plan. And since we certainly have no time to spare, I trust that, if we remain resolute, great things for the euro area and its citizens can become possible.

The full speech is here:

A consistent strategy for a sustained recovery

Updated at 4.33pm GMT

3.44pm GMT

It's been a busy day for European Central Bank members opining about future stimulus measures.

Finland's central bank governor and ECB council member Erkki Liikanen told the Wall Street Journal that it was open to negative interest rates:

Setting a negative deposit rate to guard against excessively low inflation is an option for the European Central Bank, said...Liikanen, the latest indication that officials are willing to provide fresh stimulus to protect a fragile economic recovery.

"If you want to tackle the issues with traditional monetary policy, then you should be able to cut rates further. We are at low levels but we haven't exhausted our maneuvering room," Mr. Liikanen told The Wall Street Journal in an interview.

"The question of negative deposit rates, in my mind, isn't any longer a controversial issue," he said.

The full interview is here:

ECB's Liikanen: Open to Negative Deposit Rate

Updated at 3.51pm GMT

3.30pm GMT

More US housing data. New home sales fell 3.3% month on month in February to 440,000. This is around 1.1% lower than a year ago. Teunis Brosens at ING said:

This is really not that bad at all, given bad weather conditions in parts of the country. Homebuilders did have to accept a median sales price that was 1.2% lower than a year ago.

Homebuilders themselves have become a bit more cautious about the outlook for sales, and we agree with them on that. Further drops in new home sales and/or prices cannot be excluded. Weekly mortgage applications have not yet staged a recovery and are still about 15% lower than a year ago.

Earlier today, the January Case-Shiller 20-City home price index posted a 0.8% month on month increase (see below). Prices are now 13.2% higher than a year ago, down from a peak of 13.7% year on year back in November.

Prices have been holding up quite well so far, despite the fact that January sales were 5% lower than a year earlier. The delayed effects of bad weather, but also higher mortgage rates and a slowly increasing inventory should further slow prices in the months ahead. We expect price rises to drop to single-digit numbers in a few months’ time.

3.00pm GMT

With this, it is time to hand over to Nick Fletcher. Thankyou for all your comments. JK

2.54pm GMT

Wall Street opens higher; consumer confidence surges to six-year high

Wall Street has opened higher, buoyed by a strong consumer confidence report. Confidence hit a six-year high in March, the latest sign that the economy is regaining momentum after a period of dismal weather. The Conference Boar's index of consumer attitudes rose to 82.3, the highest since January 2008, from 78.3 in February.

The Dow Jones opened up 0.6%, the S&P was 0.5% ahead and the Nasdaq 0.7% higher.

The standoff over Crimea continues, with G-7 leaders warning Russia of further sanctions if Putin took further action to destabilise Ukraine following the annexation of Crimea.

2.14pm GMT

Ukraine is in talks with the International Monetary Fund about a loan package worth $15-20bn. The Ukrainian finance minister, Oleksander Shlapak, said the ministry expected the economy to contract by 3% this year. He was confident of getting the loan package.

1.15pm GMT

Over in the US, and a house price survey has shown prices rose by slightly more than expected in January.

The S&P/Case-Schiller index of US single family home prices rose 0.8% on a seasonally adjusted month on month basis, compared to forecasts of a 0.7% increase. The year on year increase was 13.2%. On a non seasonally adjusted basis, they dipped 0.1% month on month, which was of course blamed on the cold weather. Chairman of the index committee David Blitzer said, as quoted by Reuters:

The housing recovery may have taken a breather due to the cold weather.

[But] from the bottom in 2012, prices are up 23% and the housing market is showing signs of moving forward with more normal price increases.

Updated at 1.27pm GMT

1.11pm GMT

More from the European Central Bank, and governing council member Jozef Makuch has also been talking about quantitative easing.

He said the ECB was preparing "non-standard" measures to avoid deflation, with a number of ECB board members prepared to take decisive steps if necessary.

He said there was no reason not to support QE if the circumstances showed it was needed, but there was also no reason to predict his future stance now.

Updated at 1.11pm GMT

12.33pm GMT

The euro fell today, after the European Central Bank stepped up its rhetoric about curbing the single currency's strength. Bundesbank chief Jens Weidmann, a member of the ECB's governing council, said the ECB could use interest rates to counter strong gains in the euro.

He also said it it was not out of the question for the central bank to buy assets from banks to fight deflation – a softening of the Bundesbank's strict stance on quantitative easing.

The euro dropped 0.2% to $1.3808.

Updated at 12.36pm GMT

11.52am GMT

The Treasury Committee session has finished. Watch out for the head of the OBR Robert Chote tomorrow afternoon and George Osborne next Thursday.

11.29am GMT

Asked about the cap on welfare spending and whether it will improve policy making in the future, Johnson says:

Setting it five years ahead with a 2% and a bit margin, I suspect, will not last.

It would bite much harder if we were to move into a deep recession.

He thinks it could lead to "more active decision making".

Updated at 11.31am GMT

11.11am GMT

Earlier, Citi's Michael Saunders suggested in front of the Treasury Committee that delaying fiscal tightening to the next parliament creates political risk. IFS director Paul Johnson says

Beyond 2015/16 we haven't heard from this government what the spending cuts are.

There are three years of very big spending cuts pencilled in and we know next to nothing about what they are.

Updated at 11.19am GMT

11.05am GMT

11.03am GMT

More on the UK data front: The CBI's latest survey shows retail sales growth slowing in March but shops remain optimistic for next month. The retail sales balance for March dropped to 13 from 37 in February (and compared with City forecasts of 28), but the expectations balance was the highest since December 2010 at 36, versus 28 for March.

Updated at 11.50am GMT

10.55am GMT

Without taking a break, MPs on Treasury Committee are now going to quiz the Institute for Fiscal Studies on the budget, following the session with the City economists.

Updated at 10.57am GMT

10.39am GMT

10.34am GMT

At the Treasury Committee hearing into the budget, Citi's Michael Saunders has noted that a lot of the planned fiscal tightening won't happen until after the election. Fiscal tightening equivalent to 5% of GDP has been pencilled in for the next parliament. Whether that will be achieved depends on who the next government is, MPs say. Saunders concludes:

There is uncertainty as to how the current coalition would achieve that target. They haven't spelled out their plans either.

10.27am GMT

Meanwhile, the TUC is not that impressed by the fall in inflation. TUC general secretary Frances O’Grady says:

The longest fall in living standards continues.
Lower inflation is good news, but this cannot hide the longest cut in real wages since the 1870s. An average worker is getting nine pounds in pay for every ten pounds they were getting before the crash. Pay packets are about the same level that they were ten years ago. These figures underline just how far we have to go to restore living standards so that ordinary people share in the recovery. Britain needs a pay rise.

10.18am GMT

Indebted households are the next topic. Saunders is quite optimistic about households deleveraging. He says that the debt to income ratio is back to 2003 levels and is still falling, with incomes growing at twice the pace of debt.

We don't at the moment have credit-led growth; we are deleveraging more slowly.

Updated at 10.21am GMT

10.14am GMT

Back to the Treasury Committee. Michael Saunders, head of European Economics at Citi, has just noted that business investment is "really low as a share of GDP".

10.11am GMT

Figures from the British Bankers' Association showed this morning that banks approved fewer mortgages in February than in January while the total amount of lending to buy homes rose to its highest level in nearly two years.

Mortgages for homes purchases slipped back to 47,550 last month, down from 49,341 in January which was the highest level since 2007. BBA data don't include lending by building societies, which are included in separate Bank of England data next due for release on 31 March.

The ONS reported house prices up 0.6% month-on-month and 6.8% year-on-year in January.

Updated at 10.51am GMT

10.06am GMT

The Treasury Committee hearing into the budget has got under way. You can watch it live here.

10.00am GMT

Chris Williamson, chief economist at data group Markit, notes that the fall in inflation to 1.7%, a four-year low, enables the Bank of England to keep interest rates low for longer.

The big uncertainty for the outlook for inflation lies with wages and salaries, which are finally starting to show signs of rising. The question is whether they will rise enough to worry policymakers into tightening policy sooner than currently envisaged.

The general expectation is that inflation is likely to continue to run at or below the Bank of England's 2.0% target for some time, subdued by lower import costs, resulting in turn from sterling's appreciation this year, as well as lower global commodity and energy prices. This means policymakers have greater leeway to keep interest rates at the record low of 0.5% for longer, as the economy goes through a 'sweet spot' of robust economic growth, falling unemployment and low inflation.

"The big uncertainty is pay growth, a revival of which will threaten the Bank's easy-money stance. The potential for wages to start rising strongly should not be underestimated, given the speed with which the labour market is improving. The latest official data showed average wages and salaries rising 1.4% on a year ago in the three months to January. While this means the squeeze on real pay from inflation is now at it lowest since April 2010, helping to engender a long-awaited consumer fell-good factor, it raises the possibility that the Bank could grow more worried about the possibility of wage growth in inflation is wager growth accelerates. There are already some signs of this: digging deeper into the official data reveals that pay growth has already in fact risen to an inflation-busting 3.2% in manufacturing, 3.0% in construction and 3.7% in retail, hotels and restaurants. Weak financial services and public sector pay growth remains an overall drag on earnings, but elsewhere the tightening labour market is finally feeding through to higher real-terms pay.

Without the fall in inflation, there would undoubtedly be a rising clamour for policymakers to tighten policy to ward off fears of overheating, especially given the recent housing market upturn. Key to how long the Bank of England can keep rates low therefore will be earnings growth. If we see growth of wages and salaries pick up sharply in coming months, concerns about the feed-through to higher inflation will intensify, as will the pressure on policymakers to take some of the heat out of the economy via a first hike in interest rates.

Updated at 10.01am GMT

9.46am GMT

Also out just now, factory-gate inflation in the UK has eased to the lowest since October 2009.

9.41am GMT

Back to the German Ifo business morale number, which fell to a five-month low. The monthly survey is based on a poll of some 7,000 firms.

Ifo economist Klaus Wohlrabe told Reuters:

In view of the Crimea crisis, a certain caution has returned to the German economy. The word 'uncertainty' would be too strong. There are so far no concrete effects on the German economy.

David Brown of New View Economics was more pessimistic:

The March dip in Germany's Ifo index provides further evidence that the Ukraine crisis is spilling over with negative effect to hurt business confidence. Germany's recovery could be put at risk the more the crisis deepens.

Updated at 9.44am GMT

9.38am GMT

Here are more details on inflation. Transport costs made the biggest downward contribution to the inflation rate, driven by falling petrol and other fuel prices. Smaller price rises for household gas and electricity bills than in February last year, as well as for clothes and shoes also eased price pressures, the Office for National Statistics said.

The pound rose on the news, hitting a session high of $1.6510.

Updated at 9.42am GMT

9.32am GMT

Inflation hits 4-year low of 1.7%

Inflation in Britain has hit a new four-year low in February – 1.7% – dipping further below the Bank of England's 2% target and easing the squeeze on household incomes. The gap between inflation and average wage growth is now the smallest since April 2010, the Office for National Statistics said. The last time wages grew faster than inflation was in early 2008.

Updated at 9.35am GMT

9.30am GMT

The FTSE 100 is now up 1.1%, or 72 points at 6592.40, bouncing back from yesterday's seven-week closing low. Easyjet and Kingfisher are the biggest risers, while Royal Mail is leading the pack of losers.

9.17am GMT

Impressed but not shocked – ING analyst Carsten Brzeski's verdict on the German Ifo confidence numbers.

Judging from the just released Ifo index, German businesses are impressed but not shocked by the possible economic impact from the Crimean crisis. The Ifo index dropped in March to 110.7, from 111.3 in February. While the expectations component weakened as a result of the Crimean crisis, the current assessment component continued its impressive upward trend and reached the highest level since April 2012.
The German economy is gaining momentum. The exceptionally mild weather has given an enormous boost to construction activity, with new orders in construction up by more than 10% yoy in January. In addition, the well-known growth drivers like the strong labour market, low inventories and filled order books are also doing their work. Looking ahead, two factors will be highly important for the future path of the German economy: external demand and domestic investment. As regards external demand, risks and uncertainties have clearly increased since the start of the year. The slowdown in some emerging market economies, the Russian-Ukrainian crisis and, above all, concerns about the Chinese economy do not bode well for German exports. As regards domestic investment, this is the growth wild card for the German economy. Weak domestic investment has become one of the unpleasant characteristics of the economic performance of the last ten years. In our view, weak private investment is a result of structural and cyclical factors. While cyclical factors have clearly improved, as eg favourable financing conditions and record high gross operating surpluses of German companies, uncertainty and production facilities which are not yet used to capacity could put a speed limit on investment growth. Capacity utilization rates, for example, are still clearly below past peak levels. All in all, today’s Ifo index sends two messages: the German economy has again entered the fast lane in the first quarter but continuing the ride at maximum speed will not be an easy task.

9.11am GMT

German business confidence shows first fall in five months

German business confidence has fallen for the first time in five months, not surprising given Germany's exposure to Russia and China. The latest business climate index from the Munich-based think tank Ifo has dropped to 110.7 in March from 111.3 in February. It's a mixed bag, however: The expectations component has also worsened, to 106.4 from 108.3, while the business conditions measure has strenghtened to 115.2 from 114.4.

Updated at 9.18am GMT

9.09am GMT

With Britain's economy on the mend and gold prices falling, is the "age of the pawnbroker" over? Pawnbrokers Albemarle & Bond have called in administrators, PricewaterhouseCoopers. As we reported yesterday, lenders have pulled the plug on the firm's turnaround plan, leaving investors little hope of getting their money back. The shares are suspended yesterday. My colleague Jennifer Rankin wrote last night:

Albemarle & Bond, which also provides short-term loans, has experienced a sweeping reversal of fortunes since it boasted of "the age of the pawnbroker" in 2011 and launched pop-up shops specialising in gold dealing.

Following two profits warnings last autumn, it parted company with five of its six directors, saw its share price crash and was forced to melt down its gold reserves to raise emergency cash.

Updated at 9.21am GMT

8.59am GMT

Over in Ukraine, the country's acting defence minister offered to step down over his handling of Russia's annexation of Crimea, but his resignation was turned down by parliament, a day after Ukraine began pulling out troops from the Black Sea peninsula.

8.55am GMT

The Treasury Committee starts the first hearings on last week's budget this morning. First up,

At 10.00am:

· Paul Mortimer-Lee, Global Head, Market Economics, BNP Paribas

· Michael Saunders, Head of European Economics, Citi

· Robert Wood, Chief UK Economist, Berenberg Bank

At 10.45am (approx):

· Paul Johnson, Director, Institute for Fiscal Studies

· Gemma Tetlow, Programme Director, Pensions, Savings and Public Finances Institute for Fiscal Studies

Tomorrow afternoon at 2.45pm, Robert Chote, who chairs the Office for Budget Responsibility, will be quizzed about the budget by MPs.

The chancellor himself will appear before the committee next Thursday 3 April.

8.31am GMT

As well as the latest UK inflation figures and factory-gate prices for February, we are also getting bank lending data for February from the British Bankers' Association at 9.30am GMT, which are likely to show a further increase in new loans for house purchases to the highest level since the autumn of 2007; and the CBI’s retail sales survey at 11am GMT, the first snapshot of highstreet activity in March.

The Daiwa economics team have looked at the eurozone:

After yesterday’s flash PMIs saw the average composite PMI rise more than 1pt in Q114 to the highest since Q211, today brings further business sentiment data which are likely to signal continued economic recovery at the start of 2014.

In particular, the German Ifo indices are expected to remain elevated in March, with the current assessment index expected to step up further from February’s near two-year high. And broadly consistent with yesterday’s flash PMIs, the latest French INSEE indices just released suggested that the business climate improved, albeit only slightly, in March, with the headline indicator up 1pt to 95, the highest since November but still 5pts below the long-run average. According to the detail, conditions in the industrial sector remained favourable at the long-run average, with slight improvements recorded in the retail, wholesale, other services and construction sectors. And the survey’s ‘turning point’ indicator also signalled expansion.

Updated at 9.31am GMT

8.20am GMT

European markets open higher

Markets have opened higher as expected: The Footsie is up 0.88%, Germany's Dax and France's Cac are over 0.5% ahead, Spain's Ibex has gained 0.7% and Italy's FTSE MIB has climbed 0.8%.

Updated at 9.24am GMT

8.18am GMT

Royal Mail cuts 1,600 jobs and other corporate news

Here's a round-up of this morning's corporate news. Newly-privatised Royal Mail announced that it was cutting a net 1,300 managerial and head office jobs in an attempt to save £50m a year. The job losses won't affect postmen or women. Royal Mail, which has already shed 50,000 jobs in the last 11 years, has started talks with the Communication Workers Union and Unite about the planned latest cuts. It wants to cut 1,600 jobs but will create 300 new roles at the same time. Royal Mail was sold off last October – Britain's biggest privatisation for decades. Royal Mail shares are the biggest faller on the FTSE 100 this morning.

Embattled insurance group RSA has unveiled a heavily-discounted £773m rights issue, offering three for eight shares at 56p a share – that's a 40% discount on Monday's closing price. Last month the new RSA chief executive, former RBS boss Stephen Hester, launched a drive to raise up to £1.6bn in capital.

B&Q owner Kingfisher delighted investors with the news that it will return £200m to shareholders this year. Annual profits met City expectations, rising 4% to £744m, with sales up 3.5%. Kingfisher, which also runs Screwfix, as well as Castorama and Brico Depot in France, is looking for a strategic partner for its lossmaking B&Q China business, aiming to replicate the partner approach it adopted in Turkey. Kingfisher shares were among the biggest risers on the FTSE 100 in early trading.

Easyjet shares also rose after the budget airline upgraded its first-half outlook by 25%. It now expects a pretax loss of £55m to £65m, rather than the previously indicated £70m to £90m.

Updated at 12.04pm GMT

8.00am GMT

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the financial markets, the world economy, the eurozone and business.

European shares are expected to bounce back after yesterday's heavy losses. Spreadbetters are expecting Germany's Dax to open 0.4% higher while Britain's FTSE 100 index and France's CAC are set to rise 0.3%.

Concerns over Ukraine and weaker-than-expected US manufacturing numbers weighed on markets yesterday, while some of the selling was also due to investors unwinding positions ahead of the end of the quarter.

Today investors will be watching the German business confidence report from the Ifo institute, out at 9am GMT, along with UK inflation numbers, out at 9.30am GMT.

Germany's ZEW survey showed worsening sentiment last week and Ifo could be similar, given Germany's exposure to the slowing Chinese economy and Russia. Manufacturing and services PMI surveys out yesterday also suggested growth could be plateauing in Germany.

In the UK the squeeze on consumer incomes looks set to ease, with inflation expected to have fallen to 1.7% in February from 1.9% the month before. This would be the lowest inflation rate since November 2009, when it was 1.5%.

Michael Hewson, chief market analyst at CMC Markets UK, says:

Expectations about some form of imminent monetary stimulus from China have been rising, and this appears to be helping boost sentiment, but these are likely to be misplaced given the Chinese authorities determination to make their banks more circumspect in their lending practices.

In the last few days the overall direction for European markets has been somewhat difficult to predict with Europe’s core indices well off their 2014 highs, even though Italian markets posted multi year highs last week.

Investor sentiment is being pulled all over the place as markets wrestle with a prospective improvement in European economic data against a backdrop of geopolitical uncertainty in Ukraine, Russia and Turkey, as well as fears of a slowdown in China, at the same time as the US Federal Reserve continues to dial back its stimulus dial.

Yesterday’s manufacturing PMI data while not terrible was still below market expectations for both Germany and the US and when set against the prospect of a reduction in stimulus left investors few reasons to indulge in fresh buying of stocks.

Updated at 8.26am GMT

The extravanza had been put on hold by the former socialist prime minister George Papandreou when Greece was forced to turn to the EU, ECB and IMF for emergency rescue funds to avert bankruptcy in May 2010. But addressing reporters after the parade, the defence minister Dimitirs Avramopoulos said the display had sent “a message of self-confidence” that highlighted the country’s economic recovery. “Now that Greece has got through the worst, let us all work together for the better things that are on the horizon,” he said. “We have sent with this grand parade that so many thousands of Athenians and all of Greece has watched, a message of strength and peace … the Greece of crisis very shortly will not exist [because] the Greece of pride, self-confidence and strength is coming.” The Greek president Karolos Papoulias went further likening the nation’s fight for freedom to the battle against foreign lenders much blamed for a four-year diet of austerity that has plunged the country into prolonged recession and record levels of poverty and unemployment. “Today our people are waging a struggle to break the encirclement of creditors,” the 84-year-old head of state told reporters. “Our history guarantees that this fight will be victorious.” With the plight of ordinary Greeks, hit by successive pay and pension cuts and tax increases worst than it has even been, the display of military might has been quick to spark controversy. Papandreou’s decision is believed to have brought down costs dramatically - from €3.1m to €350,000 for national day celebrations and those marking OXI day commemorating the beginning of Greece’s participation in World War II. Security was such that with the exception of a smattering of invited officials, Greeks were unable to even get close to the parade. “It’s not just an outdated display of nationalism that has no place in Europe but an incredible waste of money at a time when economically things are better but nowhere near as successful as the government makes out,” the political commentator Paschos Mandravelis told the Guardian. “A lot of money has been spent needlessly on fuel and transport of all this equipment and to make things worse, most Greeks weren’t even able to see the parade. “ Here is the official statement on the Lloyds share sale: Intention to Dispose c. 7.5% Lloyds Banking Group The news came after the market closed so has had no effect on the Lloyds shares price, which ended 0.61p higher at 79.11p. The government has just announced it plans to sell 5.35bn Lloyds Banking Group shares, or 7.5% of the group, in a placing to institutional investors. This will cut the government's stake from 32.7% to around 25% and would raise just over £4bn at the current 79p share price. And after the comments from members of the European Central Bank's council on the prospect of further stimulus measures, comes president Mario Draghi himself, echoing the same theme. Speaking in Paris, the ECB president said the central bank was ready to act if inflation slipped lower than it expected, that is, rising to 1% this year, 1.3% in 2015 and 1.5% in 2016, according to Reuters. He said: If any downside risks to this scenario appear, we stand ready to take additional monetary policy measures that ensure our mandate is fulfilled. We will do what is needed to maintain price stability. Earlier various members of the ECB had hinted at the possible measures, including negative deposit rates and quantitative easing. Draghi also said banks should take prompt action to fix any problems before the ECB unveiled its health checks on the sector, due in October. He said: The cleaning up of bank balance sheets does not need to wait for the end of this assessment. The best outcome is one where banks are forward looking and take any corrective action before the end of the process. And he concluded: Winston Churchill said that “to achieve great things, two things are needed: a plan, and not quite enough time”. I hope that I have made clear today that we do have a plan. And since we certainly have no time to spare, I trust that, if we remain resolute, great things for the euro area and its citizens can become possible. The full speech is here: A consistent strategy for a sustained recovery It's been a busy day for European Central Bank members opining about future stimulus measures. Finland's central bank governor and ECB council member Erkki Liikanen told the Wall Street Journal that it was open to negative interest rates: Setting a negative deposit rate to guard against excessively low inflation is an option for the European Central Bank, said...Liikanen, the latest indication that officials are willing to provide fresh stimulus to protect a fragile economic recovery. "If you want to tackle the issues with traditional monetary policy, then you should be able to cut rates further. We are at low levels but we haven't exhausted our maneuvering room," Mr. Liikanen told The Wall Street Journal in an interview. "The question of negative deposit rates, in my mind, isn't any longer a controversial issue," he said. The full interview is here: ECB's Liikanen: Open to Negative Deposit Rate More US housing data. New home sales fell 3.3% month on month in February to 440,000. This is around 1.1% lower than a year ago. Teunis Brosens at ING said: This is really not that bad at all, given bad weather conditions in parts of the country. Homebuilders did have to accept a median sales price that was 1.2% lower than a year ago. Homebuilders themselves have become a bit more cautious about the outlook for sales, and we agree with them on that. Further drops in new home sales and/or prices cannot be excluded. Weekly mortgage applications have not yet staged a recovery and are still about 15% lower than a year ago. Earlier today, the January Case-Shiller 20-City home price index posted a 0.8% month on month increase (see below). Prices are now 13.2% higher than a year ago, down from a peak of 13.7% year on year back in November. Prices have been holding up quite well so far, despite the fact that January sales were 5% lower than a year earlier. The delayed effects of bad weather, but also higher mortgage rates and a slowly increasing inventory should further slow prices in the months ahead. We expect price rises to drop to single-digit numbers in a few months’ time. With this, it is time to hand over to Nick Fletcher. Thankyou for all your comments. JK Wall Street has opened higher, buoyed by a strong consumer confidence report. Confidence hit a six-year high in March, the latest sign that the economy is regaining momentum after a period of dismal weather. The Conference Boar's index of consumer attitudes rose to 82.3, the highest since January 2008, from 78.3 in February. The Dow Jones opened up 0.6%, the S&P was 0.5% ahead and the Nasdaq 0.7% higher. The standoff over Crimea continues, with G-7 leaders warning Russia of further sanctions if Putin took further action to destabilise Ukraine following the annexation of Crimea. Ukraine is in talks with the International Monetary Fund about a loan package worth $15-20bn. The Ukrainian finance minister, Oleksander Shlapak, said the ministry expected the economy to contract by 3% this year. He was confident of getting the loan package. Over in the US, and a house price survey has shown prices rose by slightly more than expected in January. The S&P/Case-Schiller index of US single family home prices rose 0.8% on a seasonally adjusted month on month basis, compared to forecasts of a 0.7% increase. The year on year increase was 13.2%. On a non seasonally adjusted basis, they dipped 0.1% month on month, which was of course blamed on the cold weather. Chairman of the index committee David Blitzer said, as quoted by Reuters: The housing recovery may have taken a breather due to the cold weather. [But] from the bottom in 2012, prices are up 23% and the housing market is showing signs of moving forward with more normal price increases. More from the European Central Bank, and governing council member Jozef Makuch has also been talking about quantitative easing. He said the ECB was preparing "non-standard" measures to avoid deflation, with a number of ECB board members prepared to take decisive steps if necessary. He said there was no reason not to support QE if the circumstances showed it was needed, but there was also no reason to predict his future stance now. The euro fell today, after the European Central Bank stepped up its rhetoric about curbing the single currency's strength. Bundesbank chief Jens Weidmann, a member of the ECB's governing council, said the ECB could use interest rates to counter strong gains in the euro. He also said it it was not out of the question for the central bank to buy assets from banks to fight deflation – a softening of the Bundesbank's strict stance on quantitative easing. The euro dropped 0.2% to $1.3808. The Treasury Committee session has finished. Watch out for the head of the OBR Robert Chote tomorrow afternoon and George Osborne next Thursday. Asked about the cap on welfare spending and whether it will improve policy making in the future, Johnson says: Setting it five years ahead with a 2% and a bit margin, I suspect, will not last. It would bite much harder if we were to move into a deep recession. He thinks it could lead to "more active decision making". Earlier, Citi's Michael Saunders suggested in front of the Treasury Committee that delaying fiscal tightening to the next parliament creates political risk. IFS director Paul Johnson says Beyond 2015/16 we haven't heard from this government what the spending cuts are. There are three years of very big spending cuts pencilled in and we know next to nothing about what they are. More on the UK data front: The CBI's latest survey shows retail sales growth slowing in March but shops remain optimistic for next month. The retail sales balance for March dropped to 13 from 37 in February (and compared with City forecasts of 28), but the expectations balance was the highest since December 2010 at 36, versus 28 for March. Without taking a break, MPs on Treasury Committee are now going to quiz the Institute for Fiscal Studies on the budget, following the session with the City economists. At the Treasury Committee hearing into the budget, Citi's Michael Saunders has noted that a lot of the planned fiscal tightening won't happen until after the election. Fiscal tightening equivalent to 5% of GDP has been pencilled in for the next parliament. Whether that will be achieved depends on who the next government is, MPs say. Saunders concludes: There is uncertainty as to how the current coalition would achieve that target. They haven't spelled out their plans either. Lower inflation is good news, but this cannot hide the longest cut in real wages since the 1870s. An average worker is getting nine pounds in pay for every ten pounds they were getting before the crash. Pay packets are about the same level that they were ten years ago. These figures underline just how far we have to go to restore living standards so that ordinary people share in the recovery. Britain needs a pay rise. Indebted households are the next topic. Saunders is quite optimistic about households deleveraging. He says that the debt to income ratio is back to 2003 levels and is still falling, with incomes growing at twice the pace of debt. We don't at the moment have credit-led growth; we are deleveraging more slowly. Back to the Treasury Committee. Michael Saunders, head of European Economics at Citi, has just noted that business investment is "really low as a share of GDP". Figures from the British Bankers' Association showed this morning that banks approved fewer mortgages in February than in January while the total amount of lending to buy homes rose to its highest level in nearly two years. Mortgages for homes purchases slipped back to 47,550 last month, down from 49,341 in January which was the highest level since 2007. BBA data don't include lending by building societies, which are included in separate Bank of England data next due for release on 31 March. The ONS reported house prices up 0.6% month-on-month and 6.8% year-on-year in January. The Treasury Committee hearing into the budget has got under way. You can watch it live here. Chris Williamson, chief economist at data group Markit, notes that the fall in inflation to 1.7%, a four-year low, enables the Bank of England to keep interest rates low for longer. The big uncertainty for the outlook for inflation lies with wages and salaries, which are finally starting to show signs of rising. The question is whether they will rise enough to worry policymakers into tightening policy sooner than currently envisaged. The general expectation is that inflation is likely to continue to run at or below the Bank of England's 2.0% target for some time, subdued by lower import costs, resulting in turn from sterling's appreciation this year, as well as lower global commodity and energy prices. This means policymakers have greater leeway to keep interest rates at the record low of 0.5% for longer, as the economy goes through a 'sweet spot' of robust economic growth, falling unemployment and low inflation. "The big uncertainty is pay growth, a revival of which will threaten the Bank's easy-money stance. The potential for wages to start rising strongly should not be underestimated, given the speed with which the labour market is improving. The latest official data showed average wages and salaries rising 1.4% on a year ago in the three months to January. While this means the squeeze on real pay from inflation is now at it lowest since April 2010, helping to engender a long-awaited consumer fell-good factor, it raises the possibility that the Bank could grow more worried about the possibility of wage growth in inflation is wager growth accelerates. There are already some signs of this: digging deeper into the official data reveals that pay growth has already in fact risen to an inflation-busting 3.2% in manufacturing, 3.0% in construction and 3.7% in retail, hotels and restaurants. Weak financial services and public sector pay growth remains an overall drag on earnings, but elsewhere the tightening labour market is finally feeding through to higher real-terms pay. Without the fall in inflation, there would undoubtedly be a rising clamour for policymakers to tighten policy to ward off fears of overheating, especially given the recent housing market upturn. Key to how long the Bank of England can keep rates low therefore will be earnings growth. If we see growth of wages and salaries pick up sharply in coming months, concerns about the feed-through to higher inflation will intensify, as will the pressure on policymakers to take some of the heat out of the economy via a first hike in interest rates. Also out just now, factory-gate inflation in the UK has eased to the lowest since October 2009. Back to the German Ifo business morale number, which fell to a five-month low. The monthly survey is based on a poll of some 7,000 firms. Ifo economist Klaus Wohlrabe told Reuters: In view of the Crimea crisis, a certain caution has returned to the German economy. The word 'uncertainty' would be too strong. There are so far no concrete effects on the German economy. Germany's recovery could be put at risk the more the crisis deepens. Here are more details on inflation. Transport costs made the biggest downward contribution to the inflation rate, driven by falling petrol and other fuel prices. Smaller price rises for household gas and electricity bills than in February last year, as well as for clothes and shoes also eased price pressures, the Office for National Statistics said. The pound rose on the news, hitting a session high of $1.6510. Inflation in Britain has hit a new four-year low in February – 1.7% – dipping further below the Bank of England's 2% target and easing the squeeze on household incomes. The gap between inflation and average wage growth is now the smallest since April 2010, the Office for National Statistics said. The last time wages grew faster than inflation was in early 2008. The FTSE 100 is now up 1.1%, or 72 points at 6592.40, bouncing back from yesterday's seven-week closing low. Easyjet and Kingfisher are the biggest risers, while Royal Mail is leading the pack of losers. Impressed but not shocked – ING analyst Carsten Brzeski's verdict on the German Ifo confidence numbers. Judging from the just released Ifo index, German businesses are impressed but not shocked by the possible economic impact from the Crimean crisis. The Ifo index dropped in March to 110.7, from 111.3 in February. While the expectations component weakened as a result of the Crimean crisis, the current assessment component continued its impressive upward trend and reached the highest level since April 2012. The German economy is gaining momentum. The exceptionally mild weather has given an enormous boost to construction activity, with new orders in construction up by more than 10% yoy in January. In addition, the well-known growth drivers like the strong labour market, low inventories and filled order books are also doing their work. Looking ahead, two factors will be highly important for the future path of the German economy: external demand and domestic investment. As regards external demand, risks and uncertainties have clearly increased since the start of the year. The slowdown in some emerging market economies, the Russian-Ukrainian crisis and, above all, concerns about the Chinese economy do not bode well for German exports. As regards domestic investment, this is the growth wild card for the German economy. Weak domestic investment has become one of the unpleasant characteristics of the economic performance of the last ten years. In our view, weak private investment is a result of structural and cyclical factors. While cyclical factors have clearly improved, as eg favourable financing conditions and record high gross operating surpluses of German companies, uncertainty and production facilities which are not yet used to capacity could put a speed limit on investment growth. Capacity utilization rates, for example, are still clearly below past peak levels. All in all, today’s Ifo index sends two messages: the German economy has again entered the fast lane in the first quarter but continuing the ride at maximum speed will not be an easy task. German business confidence has fallen for the first time in five months, not surprising given Germany's exposure to Russia and China. The latest business climate index from the Munich-based think tank Ifo has dropped to 110.7 in March from 111.3 in February. It's a mixed bag, however: The expectations component has also worsened, to 106.4 from 108.3, while the business conditions measure has strenghtened to 115.2 from 114.4. With Britain's economy on the mend and gold prices falling, is the "age of the pawnbroker" over? Pawnbrokers Albemarle & Bond have called in administrators, PricewaterhouseCoopers. As we reported yesterday, lenders have pulled the plug on the firm's turnaround plan, leaving investors little hope of getting their money back. The shares are suspended yesterday. My colleague Jennifer Rankin wrote last night: Albemarle & Bond, which also provides short-term loans, has experienced a sweeping reversal of fortunes since it boasted of "the age of the pawnbroker" in 2011 and launched pop-up shops specialising in gold dealing. Following two profits warnings last autumn, it parted company with five of its six directors, saw its share price crash and was forced to melt down its gold reserves to raise emergency cash. Over in Ukraine, the country's acting defence minister offered to step down over his handling of Russia's annexation of Crimea, but his resignation was turned down by parliament, a day after Ukraine began pulling out troops from the Black Sea peninsula. The Treasury Committee starts the first hearings on last week's budget this morning. First up, At 10.00am: · Paul Mortimer-Lee, Global Head, Market Economics, BNP Paribas · Michael Saunders, Head of European Economics, Citi · Robert Wood, Chief UK Economist, Berenberg Bank At 10.45am (approx): · Paul Johnson, Director, Institute for Fiscal Studies · Gemma Tetlow, Programme Director, Pensions, Savings and Public Finances Institute for Fiscal Studies Tomorrow afternoon at 2.45pm, Robert Chote, who chairs the Office for Budget Responsibility, will be quizzed about the budget by MPs. The chancellor himself will appear before the committee next Thursday 3 April. As well as the latest UK inflation figures and factory-gate prices for February, we are also getting bank lending data for February from the British Bankers' Association at 9.30am GMT, which are likely to show a further increase in new loans for house purchases to the highest level since the autumn of 2007; and the CBI’s retail sales survey at 11am GMT, the first snapshot of highstreet activity in March. The Daiwa economics team have looked at the eurozone: After yesterday’s flash PMIs saw the average composite PMI rise more than 1pt in Q114 to the highest since Q211, today brings further business sentiment data which are likely to signal continued economic recovery at the start of 2014. In particular, the German Ifo indices are expected to remain elevated in March, with the current assessment index expected to step up further from February’s near two-year high. And broadly consistent with yesterday’s flash PMIs, the latest French INSEE indices just released suggested that the business climate improved, albeit only slightly, in March, with the headline indicator up 1pt to 95, the highest since November but still 5pts below the long-run average. According to the detail, conditions in the industrial sector remained favourable at the long-run average, with slight improvements recorded in the retail, wholesale, other services and construction sectors. And the survey’s ‘turning point’ indicator also signalled expansion. Markets have opened higher as expected: The Footsie is up 0.88%, Germany's Dax and France's Cac are over 0.5% ahead, Spain's Ibex has gained 0.7% and Italy's FTSE MIB has climbed 0.8%. Here's a round-up of this morning's corporate news. Newly-privatised Royal Mail announced that it was cutting a net 1,300 managerial and head office jobs in an attempt to save £50m a year. The job losses won't affect postmen or women. Royal Mail, which has already shed 50,000 jobs in the last 11 years, has started talks with the Communication Workers Union and Unite about the planned latest cuts. It wants to cut 1,600 jobs but will create 300 new roles at the same time. Royal Mail was sold off last October – Britain's biggest privatisation for decades. Royal Mail shares are the biggest faller on the FTSE 100 this morning. Embattled insurance group RSA has unveiled a heavily-discounted £773m rights issue, offering three for eight shares at 56p a share – that's a 40% discount on Monday's closing price. Last month the new RSA chief executive, former RBS boss Stephen Hester, launched a drive to raise up to £1.6bn in capital. B&Q owner Kingfisher delighted investors with the news that it will return £200m to shareholders this year. Annual profits met City expectations, rising 4% to £744m, with sales up 3.5%. Kingfisher, which also runs Screwfix, as well as Castorama and Brico Depot in France, is looking for a strategic partner for its lossmaking B&Q China business, aiming to replicate the partner approach it adopted in Turkey. Kingfisher shares were among the biggest risers on the FTSE 100 in early trading. Easyjet shares also rose after the budget airline upgraded its first-half outlook by 25%. It now expects a pretax loss of £55m to £65m, rather than the previously indicated £70m to £90m. Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the financial markets, the world economy, the eurozone and business. European shares are expected to bounce back after yesterday's heavy losses. Spreadbetters are expecting Germany's Dax to open 0.4% higher while Britain's FTSE 100 index and France's CAC are set to rise 0.3%. Concerns over Ukraine and weaker-than-expected US manufacturing numbers weighed on markets yesterday, while some of the selling was also due to investors unwinding positions ahead of the end of the quarter. Today investors will be watching the German business confidence report from the Ifo institute, out at 9am GMT, along with UK inflation numbers, out at 9.30am GMT. Germany's ZEW survey showed worsening sentiment last week and Ifo could be similar, given Germany's exposure to the slowing Chinese economy and Russia. Manufacturing and services PMI surveys out yesterday also suggested growth could be plateauing in Germany. In the UK the squeeze on consumer incomes looks set to ease, with inflation expected to have fallen to 1.7% in February from 1.9% the month before. This would be the lowest inflation rate since November 2009, when it was 1.5%. Michael Hewson, chief market analyst at CMC Markets UK, says: Expectations about some form of imminent monetary stimulus from China have been rising, and this appears to be helping boost sentiment, but these are likely to be misplaced given the Chinese authorities determination to make their banks more circumspect in their lending practices. In the last few days the overall direction for European markets has been somewhat difficult to predict with Europe’s core indices well off their 2014 highs, even though Italian markets posted multi year highs last week. Investor sentiment is being pulled all over the place as markets wrestle with a prospective improvement in European economic data against a backdrop of geopolitical uncertainty in Ukraine, Russia and Turkey, as well as fears of a slowdown in China, at the same time as the US Federal Reserve continues to dial back its stimulus dial. Yesterday’s manufacturing PMI data while not terrible was still below market expectations for both Germany and the US and when set against the prospect of a reduction in stimulus left investors few reasons to indulge in fresh buying of stocks.
